instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H_REG: What is PP3V42_G3H_REG? PP3V42_G3H_REG is another way to say PP3V42_G3H. PP3V42_G3H_REG and PP3V42_G3H are a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_TPAD_RST_L: What is SMC_TPAD_RST_L? SMC_TPAD_RST_L is a signal that comes from the trackpad that can reset the SMC when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. The trackpad having corrosion from liquid damage is a very common cause of no light on the magsafe charger & the system not turning on, when the trackpad or trackpad cable is corroded and holding this line down. .
definitions.SMC_MANUAL_RST_L: What is SMC_MANUAL_RST_L? SMC_MANUAL_RST_L resets the SMC when low.   _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.SMC_ONOF_L: What is SMC_ONOF_L? This is a typo of SMC_ONOFF_L When you see SMC_ONOF_L, assume they meant to type SMC_ONOFF_L.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green led
threads.message:
Hi,
i have this board very clean, no green led (PSU and official charger)
I have
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>=12,27V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_REG</SIGNAL>=3,42V
<SIGNAL>DCIN_ISOL_GATE</SIGNAL> = 6,8V
<SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_ISOL</SIGNAL> = 18,5V
<SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL>=2,85V ???
<RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> = 68Kohm
thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green led
threads.message:
Does the board turn on?
Try disconnecting LIO flex too.

Post voltage and diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.

Any history fault?
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green led
threads.message:
no the board don't turn on.
i have just the board and the magsafe board. i haven't green led, i don't connect the battery, it's easier to measure voltage on board.
SCL/SDA lines at 0V, SCL/SDA=0,5V in diode mode
the customer close the mac open for the night and the morning nothing, the mac doesn't start.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green led
threads.message:
Oops, this is <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> machine, no LIO board there, sorry.
RIO board present instead.

"SCL/SDA lines at 0V"
Are you sure?
You've said <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is present; where these lines are pulled-up through <RESISTOR>R5380</RESISTOR>/81.
Impossible with reported diode mode readings; unless both resistors are open.
Please check again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green led
threads.message:
i'm sorry, i forgot to switch on my power supply :(:ROFLMAO:
i have <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and SCL/SDA at 3,42V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green led
threads.message:
Try known good DCIN board.
I saw several of these boards don't turning on without Magsafe light.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green led
threads.message:
ok i change the board and now i have the green led but nothing.
all-sys-pwgd=0
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=0
<SIGNAL>PP5V0_S5</SIGNAL>=0
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOF_L</SIGNAL>=3,3V
<SIGNAL>SMC_TPAD_RST_L</SIGNAL>= 3,4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_MANUAL_RST_L</SIGNAL>=2,8V strange no?
maybe it's <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>? or SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green led
threads.message:
First clean J6100; remove if needed.
If <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> still low, remove <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and check it again.
If not present, be sure <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> is good.
If still low, then remove <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> and check it again.
SMC is the last thing to test.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green led
threads.message:
I change <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>, sometimes the <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> come to 3,3V and the mac start normally.
I try to remove <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> but same, i have <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>=1,4V
When i remove <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR>, i have fluctuant from 1,4v to 2,8V on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green led
threads.message:
"First clean J6100; remove if needed."
Did that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green led
threads.message:
no the connector is very clean (under microscope in and out).
Do you think remove connector is useful if it is clean?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green led
threads.message:
If you are sure about J6100, only SMC remains.
There could be corrosion under it, or internal problem.
Should reball it first.
Once SMC is removed, check if <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is steady high; with all other components resoldered.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green led
threads.message:
Ok i changed the SMC now the signal <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is always good.
the mac work well.
Thanks for your help
